p: In the production of microporous biopolymeric structures via supercritical CO 2 foaming, supercritical CO 2 is first contacted with the polymer in a high-pressure chamber. The supercritical CO 2 diffuses into the polymer matrix, causing the glass transition temperature ( T g) of the polymer to be lowered, and forming a solution of the polymer with CO 2. On depressurization, the CO 2 leaves the polymerâ€“CO 2 mixture and the polymer vitrify, leaving a microporous structure on the polymer. In this case, CO 2 actually acts both as a solute and a foaming agent. This section will focus of the role of CO 2 as a foaming agent to produce the microporous structure within the biopolymer matrix as a potential drug delivery platform for pharmaceutical applications.
